This class provides thread-local variables. These variables differ from * their normal counterparts in that each thread that accesses one (via its * {@code get} or {@code set} method) has its own, independently initialized * copy of the variable. {@code ThreadLocal} instances are typically private * static fields in classes that wish to associate state with a thread (e.g., * a user ID or Transaction ID).
independently initialized * copy of the variable.
This class provides thread-local variables. These variables differ from * their normal counterparts in that each thread that accesses one (via its * {@code get} or {@code set} method) has its own,
An extension of ThreadLocal that obtains its initial value from * the specified {@code Supplier}.

Method childValue is visibly defined in subclass * InheritableThreadLocal, but is internally defined here for the * sake of providing createInheritedMap factory method without * needing to subclass the map class in InheritableThreadLocal. * This technique is preferable to the alternative of embedding * instanceof tests in methods.

We don't use a fast path as with get() because it is at // least as common to use set() to create new entries as // it is to replace existing ones, in which case, a fast // path would fail more often than not.
The difference between successively generated hash codes - turns * implicit sequential thread-local IDs into near-optimally spread * multiplicative hash values for power-of-two-sized tables.
InheritableThreadLocal values pertaining to this thread. This map is * maintained by the InheritableThreadLocal class.
however, the child's value can be made an * arbitrary function of the parent's by overriding the <tt>childValue</tt> * method in this class.
Normally the child's values will be * identical to the parent's;
when a child thread is created, the * child receives initial values for all inheritable thread-local variables * for which the parent has values.
This class extends <tt>ThreadLocal</tt> to provide inheritance of values * from parent thread to child thread:
Application singletons that do not use static memory require some sort * of application configuration framework to maintain the application-wide SecurityManager instance for you
The Shiro development team prefers that SecurityManager instances are non-static application singletons * and not VM static singletons.
Provides registry capabilities only, with no factory capabilities built in. * Can for example be used for testing bean definition readers.
